articles.headline: After Post Sale, Spotlight Shines More Intensely on The Times
articles.snippet: The New York Times, one of the last of the family-owned newspapers, is optimistic about staying competitive in an increasingly digital world. Should it be?
articles.abstract: The New York Times, one of the last of the family-owned newspapers, is optimistic about staying competitive in an increasingly digital world. Should it be?
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s surely not just coincidence that great journalism was pioneered, nurtured and celebrated at America’s great family-owned newspapers: The Wall Street Journal under the Bancrofts, The Los Angeles Times under the Chandlers, The Washington Post under the Grahams and The New York Times under the Sulzbergers.

articles.headline: Win a Lottery Jackpot? Not Much Chance of That
articles.snippet: The odds of winning the top prize in Powerball or other big lottery is on a par with finding that needle in a haystack. A tall haystack.
articles.abstract: The odds of winning the top prize in Powerball or other big lottery is on a par with finding that needle in a haystack. A tall haystack.
articles.lead_paragraph: When those exceedingly lucky people come forward to claim this week’s Powerball lottery jackpot, which swelled to $448 million on Wednesday, it’s hard not to think: Somebody is winning these things, right? It could be me.

articles.headline: U.S. Said to Plan to Arrest Pair in Big Bank Loss
articles.snippet: Government authorities plan to arrest two former employees suspected of masking the size of a multibillion-dollar trading loss.
articles.abstract: Government authorities plan to arrest two former employees suspected of masking the size of a multibillion-dollar trading loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:30 p.m. | Government authorities are planning to arrest two former JPMorgan Chase employees suspected of masking the size of a multibillion-dollar trading loss, a dramatic turn in a case that tarnished the reputation of the nation’s biggest bank and spotlighted the perils of Wall Street risk-taking.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Mystery From the Grave Beside Oswald’s, Solved
articles.snippet: Conspiracy theorists and assassination buffs have been vexed for 15 years by the appearance of a granite marker next to Lee Harvey Oswald’s grave.
articles.abstract: Conspiracy theorists and assassination buffs have been vexed for 15 years by the appearance of a granite marker next to Lee Harvey Oswald’s grave.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — In a corner of the Shannon Rose Hill Cemetery, close to a chain-link fence that separates the living and the dead, a patch of ground has been worn free of grass by all who come to stare at one particular gravestone. With just a surname, the marker says it all: OSWALD.

articles.headline: In Cairo Camps, Protesters Dig in and Live On
articles.snippet: Two camps in Cairo set up by supporters of the ousted Egyptian president, Mohamed Morsi, have become the front lines in a dangerous stalemate with the military-installed government.
articles.abstract: Two camps in Cairo set up by supporters of the ousted Egyptian president, Mohamed Morsi, have become the front lines in a dangerous stalemate with the military-installed government.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Reaching the heavily sandbagged entrance to the sprawling protest camp in the northeast of this city requires navigating past makeshift brick walls and stepping around circles of stone marking the places where “martyrs” shot by the government fell dead.

articles.headline: Fox May Produce Clinton Biopic Reviled by G.O.P.
articles.snippet: NBC has come under heavy fire, especially from Republican critics, for agreeing to broadcast the series about Hillary Rodham Clinton, which may end up being produced by Fox Television Studios.
articles.abstract: NBC has come under heavy fire, especially from Republican critics, for agreeing to broadcast the series about Hillary Rodham Clinton, which may end up being produced by Fox Television Studios.
articles.lead_paragraph: The script for the proposed mini-series on the life of the possible presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton hasn’t even been written but we may already have a plot twist.

articles.headline: Threats Test Obama’s Balancing Act on Surveillance
articles.snippet: The debate has grown far larger than administration officials anticipated, with lawmakers of both parties and half of Americans calling for restraint.
articles.abstract: The debate has grown far larger than administration officials anticipated, with lawmakers of both parties and half of Americans calling for restraint.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has said he wants eventually to scale back drone strikes and steer the country away from a single-minded focus on counterterrorism. But in response to a vague yet ominous terror warning in recent days, his administration shut down nearly two dozen American embassies and consulates and waged an intense drone campaign in Yemen.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Hopeful’s Connections Jolt Bitter Virginia Race
articles.snippet: How an electric car company, a Homeland Security official and Hillary Rodham Clinton’s brother figure in to Terry McAuliffe’s campaign for governor.
articles.abstract: How an electric car company, a Homeland Security official and Hillary Rodham Clinton’s brother figure in to Terry McAuliffe’s campaign for governor.
articles.lead_paragraph: McLEAN, Va. — Frustrated by government red tape slowing his electric car company, Terry McAuliffe repeatedly sought a meeting at the Department of Homeland Security.

articles.headline: Lawless Sinai Shows Risks Rising in Fractured Egypt
articles.snippet: In the five weeks since Egypt’s military ousted the Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, the endemic violence here has spiraled into something like an insurgency.
articles.abstract: In the five weeks since Egypt’s military ousted the Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, the endemic violence here has spiraled into something like an insurgency.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHEIKH ZWAYD, Egypt — Every night at dusk, the streets of this desert town near the Israeli border empty out, and the chatter and thump of gunfire and explosives begin. Morning reveals the results: another dead soldier, another police checkpoint riddled with bullets, another kidnapping. In mid-July, the body of a local Christian shop owner was found near the town cemetery, his head severed, his torso in chains.

articles.headline: The Housing Market Is Still Missing a Backbone
articles.snippet: President Obama has waded into the debate about housing policy, but has offered few specifics on how to bring private capital back to the mortgage market.
articles.abstract: President Obama has waded into the debate about housing policy, but has offered few specifics on how to bring private capital back to the mortgage market.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN a speech in Phoenix last Tuesday, President Obama finally entered the debate over the future of United States housing policy. But his talking points offered few details about how to reduce the government’s giant footprint in the mortgage market.

articles.headline: The Workers Defense Project, a Union in Spirit
articles.snippet: The group, which focuses on the construction industry in Texas, has emerged as one of the nation’s most creative and responsive organizations for immigrant workers.
articles.abstract: The group, which focuses on the construction industry in Texas, has emerged as one of the nation’s most creative and responsive organizations for immigrant workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIKE most construction workers who come to see Patricia Zavala, the two dozen men who crowded into her office in Austin, Tex., one afternoon in March had a complaint.

articles.headline: The Fed, Lawrence Summers, and Money
articles.snippet: Among the top contenders to lead the Fed, Lawrence H. Summers has by far the most Wall Street experience and the most personal wealth.
articles.abstract: Among the top contenders to lead the Fed, Lawrence H. Summers has by far the most Wall Street experience and the most personal wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lawrence H. Summers left his job as President Obama’s top economic policy adviser at the end of 2010 to return to Harvard University, one of his first steps was to set up a roster of part-time positions that would touch on just about every corner of the financial world.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Annie Lowrey

articles.headline: For Freshmen in the House, Seats of Plenty
articles.snippet: The House Financial Services Committee, critics say, is a place with big incentives for freshman members of Congress to do special favors for the finance industry.
articles.abstract: The House Financial Services Committee, critics say, is a place with big incentives for freshman members of Congress to do special favors for the finance industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Andy Barr, a Republican from Kentucky with little experience in the intricacies of Wall Street, was among the lucky House freshmen to secure a seat on the powerful Financial Services Committee.

articles.headline: On Fate of Wild Horses, Stars and Indians Spar
articles.snippet: Free-roaming horses are at the center of a passionate dispute playing out across the West about whether federal authorities should sanction their slaughter to thin the herds.
articles.abstract: Free-roaming horses are at the center of a passionate dispute playing out across the West about whether federal authorities should sanction their slaughter to thin the herds.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seemed at first like a logical alliance for boldface names in the interconnected worlds of Hollywood and politics. Bill Richardson, a former governor of New Mexico, and the actor Robert Redford, a staunch conservationist, joined animal rights groups in a federal lawsuit to block the revival of horse slaughter in the United States, proclaiming that they were “standing with Native American leaders,” to whom horse slaughter “constitutes a violation of tribal cultural values.”

articles.headline: Korean Companies Struggle to Gain Traction in Japan
articles.snippet: It may sell one of every three smartphones and one in three TVs worldwide, but Samsung barely registers as a brand in Japan.
articles.abstract: It may sell one of every three smartphones and one in three TVs worldwide, but Samsung barely registers as a brand in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Brandishing a new Sony Xperia as she left a mobile phone shop in a trendy part of Tokyo, Nisako Hanawa, a 17-year-old student, explained that she had chosen that brand “because of its cool design and its good reputation.”

articles.headline: Path to United States Practice Is Long Slog to Foreign Doctors
articles.snippet: Despite a shortage of doctors in some parts of the United States, a trend that may worsen under the new health care law, it takes years for a foreign doctor to be licensed here.
articles.abstract: Despite a shortage of doctors in some parts of the United States, a trend that may worsen under the new health care law, it takes years for a foreign doctor to be licensed here.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of foreign-trained immigrant physicians are living in the United States with lifesaving skills that are going unused because they stumbled over one of the many hurdles in the path toward becoming a licensed doctor here.

articles.headline: A Gossip Site Finds Its Niche
articles.snippet: Mediatakeout.com, a celebrity gossip Web site, moves up in the ranks as its staff hunt down scoops.
articles.abstract: Mediatakeout.com, a celebrity gossip Web site, moves up in the ranks as its staff hunt down scoops.
articles.lead_paragraph: By 3 a.m. at the latest, Fred Mwangaguhunga is awake and trolling for gossip.

articles.headline: New Challenge for Filmmakers: Adding Dimension to 3-D Movies
articles.snippet: In general, audiences in North America are drifting back to conventional theaters, despite exhibitors’ aggressive push to 3-D.
articles.abstract: In general, audiences in North America are drifting back to conventional theaters, despite exhibitors’ aggressive push to 3-D.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — We saved Pandora. We got seasick with Pi. We danced with Gatsby, all in 3-D.

articles.headline: Technology Industry Extends a Hand to Struggling Print Media
articles.snippet: Whether from a sense of obligation, responsibility or guilt, the technology elite has taken up the cause of helping print journalism adapt to change.
articles.abstract: Whether from a sense of obligation, responsibility or guilt, the technology elite has taken up the cause of helping print journalism adapt to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: From classifieds to display ads to subscriptions, the digital age has broken the financial pillars of print journalism, leaving the industry struggling to stand on its own.

articles.headline: Magazine Writing on the Web, for Film
articles.snippet: Two top magazine writers, both of whom have optioned their nonfiction articles for movies, are starting a platform to enable other writers to do so as well.
articles.abstract: Two top magazine writers, both of whom have optioned their nonfiction articles for movies, are starting a platform to enable other writers to do so as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: To many writers, to almost anyone for that matter, Joshuah Bearman and Joshua Davis are living the dream. As accomplished practitioners of big, nonfiction magazine writing, they regularly publish articles in Wired, The New Yorker, Rolling Stone and many other A-list titles. Perhaps more important, they have, between them, optioned 18 of their articles for films, with two more in negotiation.

articles.headline: To Stay Afloat, Bookstores Turn to Web Donors
articles.snippet: For independent bookstores, crowdfunding has become the latest tactic for survival in a market that is dominated by Amazon and Barnes & Noble.
articles.abstract: For independent bookstores, crowdfunding has become the latest tactic for survival in a market that is dominated by Amazon and Barnes & Noble.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, independent bookstores have taken creative steps to fight off challenges from Amazon and the superstores by building in-house espresso bars, hosting members-only lunches with authors and selling birthday cards, toys and trinkets.

articles.headline: With I.P.O.’s on the Rise, Analysts Get New Scrutiny
articles.snippet: For years, financial industry rules have barred research analysts from pitching initial public offering business, but some say Wall Street is returning to its old ways.
articles.abstract: For years, financial industry rules have barred research analysts from pitching initial public offering business, but some say Wall Street is returning to its old ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: The market for initial public offerings has made a comeback, surging to levels not seen since before the financial crisis. At the same time, concerns have resurfaced over the role of Wall Street research analysts in these lucrative deals.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Prosecutors and F.B.I. Examine JPMorgan Over Losses
articles.snippet: People briefed on the matter say an investigation could yield a fine and a reprimand of the bank over the trading blowup known as the “London Whale.”
articles.abstract: People briefed on the matter say an investigation could yield a fine and a reprimand of the bank over the trading blowup known as the “London Whale.”
articles.lead_paragraph: As federal authorities prepare to charge criminally two former JPMorgan Chase employees suspected of misrepresenting a multibillion-dollar trading loss last year, prosecutors in Manhattan are separately exploring ways to penalize the bank over the trading blowup that has come to be known as the “London Whale.”
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Embassies Open, but Yemen Stays on Terror Watch
articles.snippet: The American Embassy in Yemen remained closed, underscoring the challenges President Obama faces in trying to reshape the nation’s counterterrorism strategy.
articles.abstract: The American Embassy in Yemen remained closed, underscoring the challenges President Obama faces in trying to reshape the nation’s counterterrorism strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American diplomatic outposts reopened throughout the Middle East on Sunday, easing the sense of imminent danger that has preoccupied the Obama administration since it learned of a possible terrorist attack from communications between two high-ranking officials of Al Qaeda two weeks ago.

articles.headline: Gays in Russia Find No Haven, Despite Support From the West
articles.snippet: Despite the breathtaking wealth and vibrant culture in its metropolises, Russia remains a country where discrimination and violence against gay people are widely tolerated.
articles.abstract: Despite the breathtaking wealth and vibrant culture in its metropolises, Russia remains a country where discrimination and violence against gay people are widely tolerated.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — If this article were published in a newspaper based in Russia, it could be labeled 18+ — like an X-rated movie — and start with the following disclaimer: “This article contains information not suitable for readers younger than 18 years of age, according to Russian legislation.”

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Seeks to Curtail Stiff Drug Sentences
articles.snippet: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced new steps intended to curb soaring spending on prisons and help correct what he regards as unfairness in the justice system.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced new steps intended to curb soaring spending on prisons and help correct what he regards as unfairness in the justice system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major shift in criminal justice policy, the Obama administration moved on Monday to ease overcrowding in federal prisons by ordering prosecutors to omit listing quantities of illegal substances in indictments for low-level drug cases, sidestepping federal laws that impose strict mandatory minimum sentences for drug-related offenses.

articles.headline: Once Dominant, BlackBerry Seeks to Avoid Oblivion
articles.snippet: BlackBerry says it is exploring a potential sale of the company or a joint venture, as the faded smartphone maker continues to cast about for a solution to its troubles.
articles.abstract: BlackBerry says it is exploring a potential sale of the company or a joint venture, as the faded smartphone maker continues to cast about for a solution to its troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:03 p.m. |  It is an unforgiving law of modern business: adapt or die.
